Regional Parliaments |seats2 = |seats3_title = Assembly of the Republic
|seats3 = |seats4_title = European Parliament |seats4 = }} The 'Socialist
Party' (, ), 'PS') is a social-democratic political party in Portugal. It was founded on 19 April
1973 in the German city of Bad MÃ¼nstereifel, by militants from Portuguese
Socialist Action ().

The current leader is AntÃ³nio JosÃ© Seguro. JosÃ© SÃ³crates, the former Prime
Minister of Portugal, was the leader of the party until 5 June 2011. The party
has currently 74 of 230 seats in the Portuguese Parliament and lost the June
2011 election. The Socialist Party stands out as about a third of its members in
the Assembly of the Republic are women.

SÃ³crates resigned as General Secretary on election night of 5 June 2011, due to
having lost the general election by a margin higher than expected. Seguro was
elected as leader of the party on 23 July, winning 68% of the vote against his
challenger, Francisco Assis, who got 32%.

PS is a member of the Progressive Alliance, Socialist International and Party of
   European Socialists, and has seven members in the European Parliament within
   the Socialists & Democrats (S&D) Group during the seventh parliament.
